problem_text:
Does there exist a non-right-orderable group which is residually finite p-group for a finite set of prime numbers p containing at least two different primes? If a group is residually finite p-group for an infinite set of primes p, then it admits a linear order (A. H. Rhemtulla, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc., 41, no. 1 (1973), 31–33).
N. Ya. Medvedev
answer: Yes, there does (P. A. Linnell, J. Algebra, 248 (2002) 605–607).
